column4: oh, i wonder if i use aptitude... and then aptitude remove...
well, problem is, unless you have ubuntu-desktop or something similar, you won't get new packages - only updates of old ones.
you'd just edit your /etc/apt/sources.list, and change all instances of dapper to edgy.
i don't quite have the setup yet, but i will soon (server install + fluxbox from source)
no, but provided you're running Ubuntu, it doesn't matter which GUI you have.
the thing is, i already attempted to follow those steps w/ my current ubuntu... WITHOUT ubuntu-desktop
it eventually caused some graphical bugs, font errors, and apt errors
but apt-get install ubuntu-desktop is a real pain... _just_ to get update manager to work
fluxbuntu is only in its developmental phase and buggy
plus, it doesnt even say which version is installed..
so, you're running ubuntu without ubuntu-desktop or anything of the sort...
ah yea.. and it was stable until i attempted to upgrade to edgy
i just had the regular gnomish install + fluxbox, and then i pretty much removed everything gnome-related with debfoster
in order to upgrade, you'll have to reinstall ubuntu-desktop (or kubuntu or xubuntu-desktop), then get rid of it afterwards.
nod, so the best way would be through aptitude, not apt, correct?
ah, on second thought i'm not sure if i want to go through a server install...i mean which program will it use for partitioning =/
or is it at least semi-graphical
